thread.title: Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera coming to Sydney as part of the 2016 line-up at Art Gallery of NSW
thread.title_full: Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera coming to Sydney as part of the 2016 line-up at Art Gallery of NSW | DailyTelegraph

author: Elizabeth Fortescue
title: Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera coming to Sydney as part of the 2016 line-up at Art Gallery of NSW
text:
Paintings by Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera will come to the Art Gallery of NSW from June to October next year — a highlight of the gallery’s 2016 exhibition schedule, announced today.
Among 40 paintings in the exhibition will be Kahlo’s Self Portrait With Monkeys, 1943, which “heralds the beginning of Frida-mania”, AGNSW curator Nicholas Chambers said.
The Mexican artist couple became cult figures after their deaths in the 1950s.
Kahlo’s pain and bodily disfigurement — a legacy of a horrific traffic accident — informed many of her often bizarre paintings. In self portraits she usually wore traditional dress, including elaborate and unusual hair styles.
Kahlo was devoted to Rivera, a socialist mural-painter and womaniser who she married, divorced and remarried.
The paintings in the exhibition, titled Frida And Diego, are drawn from the famous Gelman Collection in Mexico City.
Other Stories Awesome All Blacks lay Cardiff ghosts to rest Rugby 0 comments Will Geoffrey ever find love again? Sydney Confidential 0 comments Former NRL star ‘dragged woman down stairs’ Nsw Falconio killer ‘more like a prison guard’ Nsw What would PM’s tax return really show? Opinion 0 comments Robert Irwin’s animal instinct Celebrity Kahlo was one of the “most beloved” artists in the world, AGNSW director Michael Brand said. He first saw Kahlo’s Mexico City studio when he was 12 years old. Mexico City remains one of his favourite destinations.
Other exhibitions announced yesterday included Tang: Art Trom The Silk Road capital, opening in April 2016.
This exhibition showcases 130 artefacts from the Chinese province of Shaanxi in the so-called “golden age” of Chinese culture.
An Australian-based exhibition, When Silence Falls, presents the work of artists responding to the violence of often unacknowledged events such as massacres, ethnic cleansing, cultural displacement and political oppression. It opens on December 19 this year.
An exhibition of indigenous art, called Milingimbi, focuses on barks and other works from this community in central Arnhem Land. It opens on November 12, 2016.
The Dobell Australian Drawing Biennial will run from July to December 2016 with works by artists Noel McKenna, Jumaadi, Richard Lewer, Maria Kontis, Catherine O’Donnell and Nyapanyapa Yunupingu.
Curator Anne Ryan said O’Donnell will do a scale wall drawing of a fibro house in her photo realistic style.
Richard Lewer has drawn portraits of friends who suffer from depression.
The AGNSW will again be a major venue for the Biennale of Sydney, from March 18 to June 5, 2016.
The Brett Whiteley Studio in Surry Hills, managed by the AGNSW, will include exhibitions on Whiteley’s many travels as well as his artist influences.
